conclusion: An electromagnetic railgun fire truck launches fire extinguishing projectiles into high-rise buildings using electromagnetic propulsion. The energy stored in capacitors is converted into the kinetic energy of the projectile through electromagnetic induction. The problem involves determining the height H at which the projectile hits the high-rise building, given the horizontal distance L=60m, muzzle velocity v0=50m/s, launch angle θ=53°, g=10m/s², and sin(53°)=0.8.

The diagram shows a fire truck with an electromagnetic railgun aimed at a high-rise building. The horizontal distance between the truck and the building is labeled as L, the height at which the projectile hits the building is labeled as H, and the launch angle is labeled as θ. The initial velocity of the projectile is labeled as v0.
The horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity can be calculated using trigonometric functions: v0x = v0 * cos(θ) and v0y = v0 * sin(θ).
The horizontal distance traveled by the projectile is given by L = v0x * t, where t is the time of flight.
The vertical position of the projectile at time t is given by y = v0y * t - (1/2) * g * t².
